awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Cascading effects of rapid and widespread mortality of a foundation tree species on animal communities in Hawaii
awd_abstract_narration:
Forests cover a third of all land area on Earth, providing numerous ecological, economic, and social benefits. However, forests worldwide are increasingly vulnerable to large-scale tree mortalities as the frequency rises of invasive pest and pathogen outbreaks. The near elimination of dominant tree species such as American chestnut trees in North America and elm trees in Europe and North America, as a result of introduced pathogens, highlights how diseases can fundamentally change the species composition of forests and lead to cascading effects on dependent animal communities. This project will measure how animal communities reliant on native Hawaiian forests change in response to a new fungal disease causing rapid and widespread mortality to the most ecologically important and abundant native tree. This research provides a unique opportunity to measure in real time changes to animal communities as a response to rapid and ongoing tree mortality, whereas most other studies documenting the effects of widespread mortality of tree species provide retroactive data long after declines. In this project researchers will directly involve underrepresented groups including Native Hawaiian and other Pacific Islanders through the direct training of undergraduate students on the research project. This project will also convene educational events throughout Hawaii Island to communicate the research results.

Few studies have quantitatively documented how ecological communities in terrestrial ecosystems respond to the large-scale loss of a foundation species that mediates ecosystem processes and creates stable conditions for inhabitant species. Recent changes in forest structure are expanding across the Hawaiian landscape as a result of rapid, disease-induced mortality of ohia lehua (Metrosideros polymorpha), the foundation tree species of Hawaiian forests. The spreading fungal pathogen (Ceratocystis spp.) poses an immediate and serious threat to the diversity, structure, and function of Hawaii's remaining native forests and reliant plants and animals. Using advances in recording technology and soundscape analysis tools developed within the growing field of soundscape ecology, the researchers will rapidly assess changes in the biodiversity of audible birds, insects, and amphibian species in areas with different baselines and rates of change in ohia mortality across the landscape. The researchers will also evaluate whether the diversity and composition of other plant species within the understory mediates how animal communities respond to structural changes in the forest canopy. The simplified island ecosystem in Hawaii allows research to more directly tease apart the interactions that support community composition and function within forest ecosystems, which will have wide application to more complex and diverse systems that are experiencing large-scale forest tree mortality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Forests worldwide are increasingly vulnerable to large-scale tree mortalities as the frequency of invasive pest and pathogen outbreaks rise. The goal of this project was to measure how animal communities reliant on native Hawaiian forests change in response to a new disease causing rapid and widespread mortality to the most ecologically important native tree in Hawaiian forests, the ʻŌhiʻa tree. We had a unique opportunity to measure in real time changes to animal communities as a response to tree mortality. We used advances in recording technology to record the soundscape of forests across Hawaiʻi Island that varied in ʻŌhiʻa mortality from little mortality (20%) to almost complete mortality (95%) of all ʻŌhiʻa trees. To control for natural differences in the species composition and abundance of animal communities among forests we used a paired design with mortality and no-mortality control areas within each forest. We found the cascading effects of mortality of a foundational tree species like ʻŌhiʻa are complex and the response of dependent animal communities may vary at the initial stages of mortality. There was no effect of ʻŌhiʻa mortality on native and non-native orthoptera communities (e.g., crickets, grasshoppers, and katydids) regardless of the level of ʻŌhiʻa mortality. However, the number of non-native frogs increased greatly in forests with ʻŌhiʻa mortality. Non-native birds declined only in forests with the highest level of ʻŌhiʻa mortality, suggesting that overall ʻŌhiʻa mortality is not having a large effect on non-native bird communities. In contrast, we found a reduction in native birds in forests with moderate to high levels of ʻŌhiʻa mortality, suggesting a negative effect of ʻŌhiʻa mortality on native bird communities. The results of this project provide evidence that animal communities will shift through time with increased mortality of ʻŌhiʻa and result in a loss of native bird communities and an increase in non-native animals communities.

This project also had important broader impacts, including offering an improved understanding of how animal communities respond to catastrophic change. Additionally, we conducted 12 outreach events to students and the local community members. The prominent role of ʻŌhiʻa trees in Hawaiian culture allowed us to make connections with the public and garner interest in how the loss ʻŌhiʻa trees in Hawaiian native forest influences dependent animal communities. In addition, we used our soundscape recordings to "bring the sounds of the forest to the people" and in turn taught students and local communities about how scientists study local issues. Moreover, this project provided training and professional development for one female undergraduate student who is a resident of the island of Kauai, and one female graduate student.
